title: Misc
text:
This website is created using Hang’s template.

Frequently used code:

Initialize:


[ -d ./chemProbing/ ] && rm -rf ./chemProbing/
mkdir ./chemProbing/ && cd ./chemProbing/
git init && git remote add origin git@github.com:chenh19/chemProbing.git


Pull:


git pull git@github.com:chenh19/chemProbing.git


Render:


quarto render analysis


Push:


git add --all && git commit -a -m "update" && git push -u origin main

title: 2025.5.7: C12/C15 mutational profiling pilot testing
text:
Reference sequences

Amplicon-1.fa


>SARS-CoV2-5UTR-Amplicon  (378 bp)
aggtttataccttcccaggtaacaaaccaaccaactttcgatctcttgtagatctgttctctaaacgaactttaaaatct
gtgtggctgtcactcggctgcgtgcttagtgcactcacgcagtataattaataactaattactgtcgttgacaggacacg
agtaactcgtctatcttctgcaggctgcttacggtttcgtccgtgttgcagccgatcatcagcacatctaggtttcgtcc
gggtgtgaccgaaaggtaagatggagagccttgtccctggtttcaacgagggagtcaaagttctgtttgccctgatctgc
atcgctgtggccgaggccaagcccaccgagaacaacgaagacttcaacatcgtggccg


Amplicon-2.fa


>SMN2-Exon7-Amplicon  (324 bp)
AACTTCCTTTATTTTCCTTACAGGGTTTTAGACAAAATCAAAAAGAAGGAAGGTGCTCACATTCCTTAAATTAAGGAGTA
AGTCTGCCAGCATTATGAAAGTGAATCTTACTTTTGTAAAACTTTATGGTTTGTGGAAAACAAATGTTTTTGAACATTTA
AAAAGTTCAGATGTTAGAAAGTTGAAAGGTTAATGTAAAACAATCAATATTAAAGAATTTTGATGCCAAAACTATTAGAT
AAAAGGTTAATCTACATCCCTACTAGAATTCTCATACTTAACTGGTTGGTTGTGTGGAAGAAACATACTTTCACAATAAA
GAGC


Combine reference sequences with  1.refseq.sh

title: 2025.5.7: C12/C15 mutational profiling pilot testing
text:
FastQC for reads

FastQC with  2.fastqc.sh

Note: I started with FastQ files (raw reads) because Plasmidsaurus didn’t have the refseq and their assembly could be wrong.
Sample-1 (representative FastQC per base quality plot):

Conclusion: within ~400bp, the reads quality is generally good.

title: 2025.5.7: C12/C15 mutational profiling pilot testing
text:
Reads mapping

Reads mapping with  3.bam.sh

Note: Minimap2 was the aligning tool used here (GitHub).It’s fast and suited for Nanopore reads (doesn’t require R1 and R2 as input). There might be better tools out there.

title: 2025.5.7: C12/C15 mutational profiling pilot testing
text:
Analyzing and visualization

Pileup with  4.mpileup.sh

Parse with  5.parse.R

About Pileup Format, here is a detailed explanation. In short, column 4 denotes the depth at specific postion, and . and , in column 5 indicate matched reads.

For parsed mutation rate spreadsheets, click here.
Plot with  6.plot.R

title: 2025.5.29-b: Project-1. Small molecule-binding RNA structural probing
text:
FastQC for reads

FastQC with  2.fastqc.sh
Sample-7_R1 (representative FastQC per base quality plot before reads trimming):

Sample-7_R2 (representative FastQC per base quality plot before reads trimming):




View all samples before reads trimming:


Sample-8_R1:

Sample-8_R2:

Sample-9_R1:

Sample-9_R2:

Sample-10_R1:

Sample-10_R2:

Sample-11_R1:

Sample-11_R2:

Sample-12_R1:

Sample-12_R2:




Conclusion: within 250bp, the reads quality is generally good. R2 has lower overall quality than R1,which is expected for paired-end reads.

title: 2025.5.29-b: Project-1. Small molecule-binding RNA structural probing
text:
Reads trimming

Reads trimming with  3.trim.sh
Key filtering standards:


1.Keeping the first 200bp and discard the tail
2.Trimming the tail with average Q-score < 20 (4 bases moving window size)
3.Discarding reads with more than 10% of Q-score < 20 bases

title: 2025.5.29-b: Project-1. Small molecule-binding RNA structural probing
text:

Re-FastQC with  4.refastqc.sh
Sample-7_R1 (representative FastQC per base quality plot after reads trimming): 
Sample-7_R2 (representative FastQC per base quality plot after reads trimming): 



View all samples after after trimming:


Sample-8_R1:

Sample-8_R2:

Sample-9_R1:

Sample-9_R2:

Sample-10_R1:

Sample-10_R2:

Sample-11_R1:

Sample-11_R2:

Sample-12_R1:

Sample-12_R2:




Conclusion: after trimming, the quality of the overall reads quality is improved and variation is reduced.

title: 2025.5.27-b: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-2)
text:
Re-analysis of 2025.5.7 dataset with reads trimming.
This batch of analysis uses the trimmed SARS-CoV2-5UTR-Amplicon instead of the full length, so that it can allow comparison with the later AVITI data.

title: 2025.5.27-b: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-2)
text:
Re-analysis of 2025.5.7 dataset with reads trimming.
This batch of analysis uses the trimmed SARS-CoV2-5UTR-Amplicon instead of the full length, so that it can allow comparison with the later AVITI data.

title: 2025.5.27-b: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-2)
text:
Reads trimming

Reads trimming with  3.trim.sh
Key filtering standards:


1.Keeping the first 400bp and discard the tail
2.Trimming the tail with average Q-score < 20 (4 bases moving window size)
3.Discarding reads with more than 20% of Q-score < 20 bases
4.Discarding reads less than 200bp

title: 2025.5.27-a: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-1)
text:
Re-analysis of 2025.5.7 dataset with reads trimming.
Q: why not including reads trimming in the first analysis? Argument: because we are trying to do mutational profiling and want to preserve as much as mutation information if possible. The overall mutation rate is low, and if we apply too stringent QC standards, we may lose signals.

title: 2025.5.27-a: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-1)
text:
Re-analysis of 2025.5.7 dataset with reads trimming.
Q: why not including reads trimming in the first analysis? Argument: because we are trying to do mutational profiling and want to preserve as much as mutation information if possible. The overall mutation rate is low, and if we apply too stringent QC standards, we may lose signals.

title: 2025.5.27-a: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-1)
text:
Reads trimming

Reads trimming with  3.trim.sh
Key filtering standards:


1.Keeping the first 400bp and discard the tail
2.Trimming the tail with average Q-score < 20 (4 bases moving window size)
3.Discarding reads with more than 20% of Q-score < 20 bases
4.Discarding reads less than 200bp

title: 2025.5.27-c: Plasmidsaurus data re-analysis (part-3)
text:
Reads trimming

Reads trimming with  3.trim.sh
Key filtering standards:


1.Keeping the first 400bp and discard the tail
2.Trimming the tail with average Q-score < 20 (4 bases moving window size)
3.Discarding reads with more than 20% of Q-score < 20 bases
4.Discarding reads less than 200bp

title: 2025.5.29-a: Amplicon-seq analysis troubleshooting
text:
Mis-mapping led to wrong variants calling (artifact at around 150bp):



This issue doesn’t always happen on all samples, and by checking the bam files, I realized it’s mis-mapping (repeated 34bp large deletion).
It seems that when the length of the insert (i.e., <300bp) between two adapters is shorter than the combination of two reads (i.e., 150bpx2), BWA can get confused.

title: 2025.5.29-a: Amplicon-seq analysis troubleshooting
text:
Mis-mapping led to wrong variants calling (artifact at around 150bp):



This issue doesn’t always happen on all samples, and by checking the bam files, I realized it’s mis-mapping (repeated 34bp large deletion).
It seems that when the length of the insert (i.e., <300bp) between two adapters is shorter than the combination of two reads (i.e., 150bpx2), BWA can get confused.

title: 2025.5.29-a: Amplicon-seq analysis troubleshooting
text:
Troubleshooting attempts

Reads trimming and filtering (both loose and stringent criteria): can’t avoid the artifact.
Mapping as paired-end reads vs separate single-end reads: can’t avoid the artifact.
Adjust the refseq by including 5’ and 3’ sequences (i.e., additional 3bp on each side), although they might not be in the mutational profiling region: this reduces mis-mapping by a little bit.
Use different aligners: Bowtie2 aligns perfectly (bam screenshot below), but has much lower variant calling sensitivity; Minimap2 has the same mis-mapping issue.



Using the same read trimming and filtering criteria (key parameters listed below), Bowtie2 detects only about half as many variants as BWA.


fastp \
  --trim_front1 5 \
  --trim_front2 5 \
  --cut_tail \
  --cut_tail_window_size 4 \
  --cut_tail_mean_quality 20 \
  --length_required 80 \
  --qualified_quality_phred 20 \
  --unqualified_percent_limit 20 \

title: 2025.5.29-a: Amplicon-seq analysis troubleshooting
text:
Final solution

# align reads
bwa index ./3.analysis/1.refseq/refseq.fa
for r1 in ./3.analysis/3.trim/*_R1*trimmed.fastq.gz; do
  [ -f "$r1" ] || continue
  r2=$(echo "$r1" | sed -E 's/_R1/_R2/')
  base=$(basename "$r1" .trimmed.fastq.gz)
  sample=$(echo "$base" | sed -E 's/_R1//')

  bwa mem -t 16 ./3.analysis/1.refseq/refseq.fa $r1 $r2 | \
    samtools sort -@ 16 -o ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.bam
  samtools index ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.bam

  bamtools filter -in ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.bam -out ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.filtered.bam -tag "NM:<34"
  samtools index ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.filtered.bam

  rm -f ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.bam ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.bam.bai
done


BWA: better for variants calling


bwa mem -t 16 ./3.analysis/1.refseq/refseq.fa $r1 $r2


bamtool: empirically filter out mis-mapped reads (large deletion)


bamtools filter -in ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.bam -out ./3.analysis/5.bam/${sample}.filtered.bam -tag "NM:<34"


The artifact at around 150bp is gone:



The mutational signals are better preserved when using BWA compared to Bowtie2:

title: 2025.5.29-a: Amplicon-seq analysis troubleshooting
text:
Conclusion

BWA mapping + bamtools filtering will be used for future amplicon-seq analysis.
